I feel like there should be a different name for the shape of the mandelbrot set, to distinguish it from the set of points that specifically is defined as the mandelbrot set. No idea if anyone else has come up with a name for it, but I suggest 'mandelbroid'.

It should be noted that the fractal patterns are generated not by the dynamics directly but by their convergence properties. So the patterns just tell us how points on the plane converge relative to other points. (e.g., similar colors = similar convergence rates) [Of course this is the dynamics but the color pattern that is graphed doesn't depend on the functional value so much as it's rate of convergence(but clearly there is a relation, it's just that the pattern really is meant to talk about convergence properties rather than function amplitude that we generally think of when graphing functions)]

It is really not that difficult to think that such patterns exist as convergence is a tricky thing. E.g., a geometric series converges for |r| < 1 and diverges for |r|>1 and when |r| ~= 1 it may or may not converge or more complex formulas(so things that are quasi-geometric may have complex convergence patterns around |r| ~= 1). The mandelbrot boundary really is just the convergence of an infinite polynomial that twists and turns as it is "twisted up" by repeated iteration. Because it is symmetric(by the squaring) it creates a very obvious pattern that we think is interesting(but really it is no more interesting than any other except it is one of the simpler patterns).

What is more important is that all recursive formulas have innate structure and that is what is far more important than any fractal itself. There is little point in studying the Mandelbrot fractal for it's own sake... but indirectly one can learn about recursion itself and recursion is the key to life. It is the recursion itself that exhibits the innate "definition" of what is being recursed and what links definitions.

The reason the Mandelbrot set appears in many parameter spaces of holomorphic dynamics is due to a phenomenon known as "polynomial-like functions". Such functions are holomorphic functions which behave locally as polynomials (and some subsets their Julia sets are homeomorphic to polynomial Julia sets). Those Mandelbrot copies you've witnessed are simply a private case of this phenomenon - there are theorems guaranteeing the existence of the Mandelbrot space in such parameter spaces, provided certain conditions are met.

If it's uncountably infinite, and they can't pass through any other point infinity many times, they must pass through every other point.

The stuff goes everywhere principle follows quite simply from the fact that any rational map coloring regions according to their limit behavior will have all colors along the boundary of the fractal. Since any two arbitrary points can be used to define a coloring and the fractal includes all colors along the boundary, this means that the points around the boundary of the fractal can go to arbitrary places. The "Stuff goes everywhere" principle explains the "Fast Julia Set" algorithm I learned when computers were slow enough that it mattered! The algorithm started with a seed point (I think 0 was always good), and a repeated application of an inverse of the iterating function. F^{-1}(z) = sqrt(z-c) - in practice, that meant converting to polar coordinates z-c = re^{i\theta}, sqrt(z-c) = sqrt(r)e^{i\theta/2} or sqrt(r)e^{i(\pi+\theta/2)} (choosing one of the roots randomly by flipping a coin). The result is the boundary is an attractor for the function.

*Solution to the 3rd exercise*: In other words the exercise tells us to prove that f'(r)=0, where r is the center of mass. After the derivation, we get to P''(r)*P(r)=0, which we have to prove. If r1,r2,r3 are the roots of the polynomial, then we know that P(r) can't be equal to 0 for every r1,r2,r3. That said, we have to focus on the other term P"(r). If we let P(z)=az^3+bz^2+cz+d then P''(z)=6az+2b. From Viette's relations we know that r1+r2+r3=-b/a, so we get P"(r)=2a*(-b/a)+2b=-2b+2b=0 for any z1,z2,z3 roots of a cubic polynomial, which results in f'(r)=0.

About the question you asked in the end, yes there is a pretty logical visual explanation that "if you take a sample, no matter how small, it will ALWAYS contain points that eventually converge on the attracting points". Not sure if I formulated it correctly, but, here it is: Since you cannot zoom and eventually find boundary with just TWO (in the example of three roots) colors, but THREE (or all N, more generally) colors, that means that it has THREE "types" of converging points (by "type" I mean to which roots it gets attracted), so after many iterations all points from that sample *MUST converge to ONE of the roots. And since you will always have all the colors (or just one) in your sample (no matter how much you zoom), therefore all the roots will get some of the sample points.
* yes, the black zones with points that don't get attracted to one of the roots, but again, they stay in the black region, so they ARE attracted by it, and black regions are attracting points.

what would a Newton's fractal for f(z) = sin(z) look like? with just real numbers, its easy to see that each crest and trough of the sine wave has an infinite number of values that approach infinity. . . this is because at the top of the hill, the slope approaches zero, and therefor the displacement of x approaches infinity, however as you go down the hill you reach a point where the sine wave passes through the x axis and the displacement of x is zero, each hill of the sine wave maps to all real numbers. . . so somewhere on that hill is a point where the displacement of x is equal to pi, which since its a sine wave, this displacement is exactly one wavelength and so the next iteration will also have the same displacement. There is also a point whose displacement per iteration is 2pi, and one for 3pi, and so on.

So every hill of the sine wave has an infinite number of points that approach infinity at a constant rate . . . it would be hard to visualize i think because of the infinite number of zeros, coloring by which zero the point approaches doesnt make as much sense anymore.

What I find fascinating about the Mandelbrot set is how well embedded it is in the cross-section of math and art. So often when a mathematical function or concept gets embraced by artists, there's a very consistent inverse relation between how aesthetically interesting it is vs how mathematically interesting it is (ie the principle that cool visuals normally means unexciting math, and exciting math normally means there's nothing much to see). Yet the Mandelbrot set and its associated Julia sets manage to be endlessly interesting in both aesthetics and mathematics.

About Montel's theorem: You don't need the full strength. It's enough to know that the union of the images of a non-normal function family is dense.
So you don't need the universal covering (j-function). And for the Newton fractal you only need to know this property for rational functions for which Montel's theorem can be deduced easier (you don't need the Cauchy integral formula for holomorphic functions).

Analogous to this is lemniscates of iterated complex functions, which are the level sets of the absolute value of the functions. For example, if you start with f_0(z) = z and iterate f_(n+1)(z) = (f_n)^2(z) + z and then plot contours in the complex plane where |f_n(z)| = some constant, then if you choose the constant 2, the contours converges to the boundary of the Mandelbrot set.

@17:37 "...it turns out -- this is not at all obvious -- ...". It seems fairly intuitive to me (the fact itself does. I'd take a long time to figure out how to prove it). That point would be the one where all roots are "equally good" in some sense, so why should it choose any particular one?

The basic identity equation y=x is a linear equation that has linearity and within itself as it bisects the XY plane it produces perfect symmetry. Also through Lambda Calculus any number system N where N is the base to some Logarithmic function with an infinite amount of digit placements is said and proven to be Turing Complete. It has or possess the ability to count and do to repetitious cycles and being repeatable through transformations or rotations also provides the ability to have an inverse as well as being able to be recursive in nature. Once you have all of these properties because of the nature of Associativity especially within addition, multiplication, function composition, logical And, OR and XOR, as well as Group Theory it is inevitable that a fractal will emerge. The Graph of the Mandelbrot Set alone which is based on the properties and relationships of numbers within a given iterative function does in fact possess the properties of being able to count as it can perform both addition and multiplication. How and why? Without first glance, the identity equation y=x or its function form f(x) = x which is a diagonal line that bisects the XY axis in the 1st and 3rd quadrant has the three trigonometric functions tan(t), sin(t), cos(t) embedded within itself.

Let's compare the identity equation with the slope-intercept form of an arbitrary given linear equation y=mx+b. Here m is the slope and b is the y-intercept. Within our identity equation y=x we can see that m is understood as 1 due to the multiplicative identity and b is understood as 0 due to the additive identity. As these two identities does not change the solution space. So where does the trigonometric functions come into play?

We need to understand the definition of slope first. It is defined as rise over run or rise/run and it can be calculated from any two points on a given line by the formula m = (y2-y1)/(x2-x1). This can also be understood as the change in y over the change in x or simply dy/dx and you will see this notation all through Calculus and within Physics and other sciences that pertain to rates of change. So far this is still all Algebra, but where does Trigonometry come into play?

We can take any given line of the form y=mx + b and substitute it with y=(dy/dx)x + b. We haven't changed anything nor its behavior. How does this relate to the trigonometric functions? Here the (dy/dx) or the slope of the function is also the tangent of the angle that is produced by the line y=mx+b and the (+)x-axis. We can now write this as y=tan(t)x + b. Through trig substitution we can now write this as y = (sin(t)/cos(t))x + b. We know that the x and y-axes are orthogonal, perpendicular to each other as they create a right angle making them either 90 degrees or PI/2 radians from each other. We know that the line y=x bisects this angle which is the same as 90/2 = 45 degrees or PI/2/2 = PI/4 radians. For simplicity of numbers I will use degrees within this example.

Now we can see that y=x is the same as y = tan(45)x + 0 = x since tan(45) = 1, and the same is true for y=(sin(45)/cos(45))x + 0 = x since sin(45)/cos(45) = sqrt(2)/2 / sqrt(2)/2 = 0.7071... / 0.7071... = 1. And here we haven't even performed any operations to our variables. We only identified them. This works because y=x is or has perfect symmetry.

I'll take this even one step farther and show that the first and simplest of all arithmetic equations 1+1=2 satisfies and defines the Pythagorean Theorem. We know that the Pythagorean Theorem is based on Right Triangles from the equation A^2 + B^2 = C^2. So how does addition of 1 onto itself that produces 2 both satisfies and defines this? We first have to establish the fact that the equation 1+1 = 2 is also a definition to the Unit Circle. Yes, it is, but first we need to understand the General Equation to any Arbitrary Circle. This is defined as (x-h)^2 + (y-k)^2 = r^2 where (h,k) is the center point of the circle, (x,y) is any point that lies on the circle and r is the length distance or magnitude of the circle's radius. The normal unit circle is typically has its center at (0,0) and its equation is reduced or simplified to, (x-0)^2 + (y-0)^2 = 1^2 == x^2 + y^2 = 1 and this is how the trigonometric functions end up having Pythagorean Identities. In our case of 1+1 = 2. This is still the unit circle only that it has been horizontally translated 1 unit toward the right along the (+)x-axis. The equation for the unit circle generated by 1+1= 2 has its center at (1,0) with a radius of 1 and is defined as (x-1)^2 + (y-0)^2 = 1^2 == (x-1)^2 + y^2 = 1. How does this work? If we take the equation to the unit circle at the origin (0,0) we can see that x^2 + y^2 = 1 is a specialized case of the Pythagorean Theorem since x^2 + y^2 = 1 is a form of A^2 + B^2 = C^2.

Another property that exists from the Pythagorean Theorem is the fact that it is the governing Theorem or basis to the Distance Formula which can be applied to any spatial dimension N where N is the degree of a given polynomial x^N where each spatial dimension of that order has exactly N orthogonal - perpendicular coordinate elements where each and every element are perpendicular to one another.

Dimensionality: Polynomial Function: Vectorized Coordinates
0D - Constant Non-Zero Constant {}
1D - Linear: f(x) = x {x}
2D - Quadratic: f(x) = x^2 {x,y}
3D - Cubic: f(x) = x^3 {x,y,z}
4D - Quartic: f(x) = x^4 {x,y,z,w}
5D - Quintic: f(x) = x^5 {x,y,z,w,v}
6D - Sextic: f(x) = x^6 {x,y,z,w,v,u}
...
ND - Approximates to a Circle or Sphere like structure: f(x) = x^N {x,y,z, ... N-2, N-1, N} where N approaches Infinity.

And if you notice each spatial dimension above and below a given polynomial order are vaguely its derivatives and integrals. For example, the derivative of f(x) = x^2 is f'(x) = 2x. And the integral of f(x) = x^2 is F(x)dx = (1/3)x^3. Here we can drop any constants or coefficients and see that 2x is of the order of x, and that (1/3)x^3 is of the order of x^3.

All of this is possible not only from 1+1 = 2, but it is embedded within y=x due to the fact that the identity equation has perfect symmetry!

Here is what I got after some thinking about it:

If we map a posibility space of infinitely many specivic starting points on to finitely many possible resulting points

Then that map will consits out of regions, where the correlation between starting and resulting point is certain and also regions, where it is uncertain.

That a region has a uncertain correlation between starting and resulting points, means that itself is a posibility space, that includes all possible results, otherwise it would not be uncertain.

Therfore the boundaries of the regions of certainty have to be uncertain and therefore self repeating.

A smooth boundary between only two options is in a way a super fractal, where any zoom in is not only self similar, but self identical.

That factoid about picking points that are extremely close in a cluster around a given pixel, and them behaving either erratically or not.. happens to be why we can supersample these sets to construct smooth images from them - if this property wasn't true then supersampling would not be possible and we'd be stuck with jarring sharp and jagged approximation images such as any naive implementation of a colouring algorithm produce when implementing visualisation from first principals. Rather love that fact

The reason super-sampling wouldn't be possible if it wasn't, comes down to "well, if half of the values are well behaved and half aren't", then you'll get a "muddy" pixel back that looks like a lot of neither, resulting in a blurry and very "nothing" image that doesn't paint much of any picture of what's going on

1a. Solving the equation we get fixed points z = (1 ± sqrt(1-4c))/2
1b. We know that for the fixed point to be an attractor, we need |f'(z)| = 2|z| < 1
Plugging in the solution from 1a we get |1 ± sqrt(1-4c)| < 1
1c. Assume w = 1 ± sqrt(1-4c). We know that w is within the unit circle
We can solve for c and get c = (2w - w^2)/4
To get the boundary we can substitute w = exp(i*t) where t ∈ (0, 2π)
If we extract real and imaginary parts of c we get x(t) = 1/2*(1-cos(t))*cos(t) + 1/4, y(t) = 1/2*(1-cos(t))*sin(t)
That corrensponds to a cardioid made with circles of radius 1/4, with the stationary circle centered at the origin, exatly the same as the one we find in the Mandelbrot set

2. To make our life a little easier we can first notice that f(0) = 1, so really g'(0) = f'(1)*f'(0)

Well, Montels theorem is just the kind of complex-function analogon of Bolzano-Weierstraß' theoream: For BOUNDED complex number sequences you get a converging sub-sequence. Montel now says: For "bounded" holomorphic function sequences you get a converging sub-sequence. Here "bounded" means that your holomorphic function at least does not hit two different complex numbers. As far as i know, you dont need the j-function for the proof, just some easy sub-sequence constructions and cantors diagonal sequence method for getting it to convergen.

My intuition for why the one-or-all colors on the boundary rule exists goes something like this:

When you've zoomed infinitely close to a boundary (as when following the the definition of a boundary; using "infinite" as a short-hand for a limit), the colors beside it, if any, must go somewhere. But, given that you're infinitely zoomed in, you can't really choose to which point of the infinitely-far roots to go towards, as they all look the same "infinity" from the zoomed in view. But, given that you're already going towards at least two (the definition of a boundary), you can only choose to go towards all of them.
Similar to how dividing numbers gives you only one result (6÷3 is only 2), or infinitely many (0÷0 can give you any result you want, depending on what "zeroes" you have).

Does this make any sense? I assume you'd have to go a lot more precise on the interaction between the infinite zoom and non-infinite end-points to have any actual working definition (besides this seemingly saying that all boundaries must be like this, not only ones for rational functions).
